Smart money is not selling. Whatever you do, DO NOT SELL a single share. Let the ex-Plaintiff and his cohorts cover their own shorts. Instead, average down at their expense. Thank me later.Here's why:Lawsuit will be settled out of court due to the recent discovery investigations on the ex-Plaintiff and his cohort's insider trading (March 13 between 3pm-4pm EST) and share swapping between accounts (Sept 23 between 3:45pm-4pm EST). Both of these charge plus new ones to be unveiled soon come with fines and jail time for all involved, directly and indirectly.FlexShopper's patent infringement lawsuit will be dropped due to lacking merit. Under U.S. patent law (35 U.S.C. ¬ß 112(b)), a patent claim can be invalidated if it is indefinite, meaning it fails to clearly define the invention's scope with reasonable certainty (renting vs leasing). If the claims are so ambiguous that a person skilled in the art cannot determine what the patent is meant to cover, the patent may be considered indefinite and therefore invalid.KPLT's algorithm is 3x more effective than SEZL and 2+x more effective than FPAY's. KPLT's bad debt is at 9.3%, while SEZL's is at 30% and FPAY at 23%.KPLT is controlling cost and expects to hit BE by year's end. FYI: WayFair is expected to bounce back in 2025. Analyst currently have it on a BUY recommendation.

You can't piece apart a patent that is flawed to meet your specific needs. It doesn't work that way. FPAY's patent is indefinite. Essentially that means if parts of it are invalid, then the entire patent is invalid.The ruling is clear and the ambiguity between 'renting' and 'leasing' as interchangeable terms is flawed. In the same way they can't claim one plus the other and treat them alike. It doesn't work that way. Patents must 'clearly define the invention's scope with reasonable certainty." Renting is not the same as Leasing. They are defined/treated differently both financially as well as legally.Under U.S. patent law (35 U.S.C. ¬ß 112(b)), a patent claim can be invalidated if it is indefinite, meaning it fails to clearly define the invention's scope with reasonable certainty. If the claims are so ambiguous that a person skilled in the art cannot determine what the patent is meant to cover, the patent may be considered indefinite and therefore invalid.

Cracks me up how FPAY is up on earnings today. If you fell for their pitch, take a closer look at two items.They boast a drop in bad debt from 33.4% to 22.5%.They plan to increase their marketing expenses by 71%.Essentially, for every $1 they lose to bad debt they need about $7 in new revenues, hence the 71% marketing expense increase is a total wash. ...and it's all because they don't use AI and ML like KPLT.FYI: KPLT's bad debt is 9.3% for Q2 showing an improvement from 9.7% in Q1. In short their algorithm is 2+x better than FPAY's.Instead FPAY moves delinquent accounts to collection agencies to hound their clients. The end result is just the opposite of what KPLT has achieved.KPLT's propensity to refer a friend is at 60%, while FPAY refuses to post their NPS score ...because it's so bad.The sign of a viable business is one that leverages their existing client base to refer new business.

Here's what the USPT states about "indefiniteness".The term used to void a patent due to ambiguity is "indefiniteness". Under U.S. patent law (35 U.S.C. ¬ß 112(b)), a patent claim can be invalidated if it is indefinite, meaning it fails to clearly define the invention's scope with reasonable certainty. Matt, don't get your hopes up. I checked all 5 patents descriptions and found numerous errors, inconsistencies, and easy loop holes in each. In fact there's glaring grounds for voiding these patents altogether.I'll share the most glaring error.Just enter any of the Patent Numbers from the article into Google and click the first option from the search.In their patent Flex states the following:"An RTO transaction is typically a type of legally documented transaction under which goods are leased or rented in exchange for a regularly scheduled payment with the option to purchase at some point during the agreement."This statement is incorrect and misleading because renting is not the same as leasing.
